sen.j: 土方 歳三（ひじかた としぞう）、天保6年5月5日 (旧暦)（1835年5月31日） - 明治2年5月11日 (旧暦)（1869年6月20日））は、新選組副長、蝦夷共和国陸軍奉行並箱館市中取締裁判局頭取。
sen.e: Toshizo HIJIKATA (6th Year of Tenpo, May 5th (Lunar Calendar)(May 31, 1835) - 2nd Year of Meiji, May 11th (Lunar Calendar)(June 20, 1869)) is the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi, vice-minister of the Army for Ezo Republic, and also chief of the Court for Torishimari of Hakodate city.

Toshizo HIJIKATA (6th year of Tenpo, May 5th (Lunar Calendar)(May 31, 1835) - 2nd year of Meiji, May 11th (Lunar Calendar)(June 20, 1869)) was the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi, vice-minister of the Army for Ezo Republic, and also chief of the Court for Torishimari of Hakodate city.
sen.cmt: 副長の表現としては、他に"sub-commander"、"vice captain"、"secretary"なども見られる箱館市中取締裁判局頭取はセル103を見ると、箱館市中取締と陸海軍裁判局頭取のことだと思われる。定訳不明
sen.e: Toshizo HIJIKATA (6th year of Tenpo, May 5th (Lunar Calendar)(May 31, 1835) - 2nd year of Meiji, May 11th (Lunar Calendar)(June 20, 1869)) was the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi, vice-minister of the Army for Ezo Republic, and also chief of the Court for Torishimari of Hakodate city.

sen.j: 諱は義豊。
sen.e: Imina is Yoshitoyo.
His imina (posthumous name) is Yoshitoyo.
His imina (posthumous name) is Yoshitoyo.

sen.j: 雅号は豊玉。
sen.e: Pseudonym is Hogyoku.
His pseudonym is Hogyoku.
His pseudonym is Hogyoku.

sen.j: 幕末期の幕臣。
sen.e: A vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate at the end of Edo Period.
He was a vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate at the end of Edo Period.
He was a vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate at the end of Edo Period.

sen.j: 新選組鬼の副長として皆に恐れられた。
sen.e: Was feared by all as the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi.
Was feared by all as the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi.
Was feared by all as the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi.

sen.j: 家紋は左三つ巴。
sen.e: Family crest is Hidari Mitsudomoe
Family crest is Hidari Mitsudomoe
Family crest is Hidari Mitsudomoe

sen.j: 武蔵国多摩郡石田(いしだ)村（現在の東京都日野市石田）に生まれる。
sen.e: Born in Ishida village, Tama district, Mussashi province (is now Ishida, Hino city, Tokyo).
He was born in Ishida village, Tama district, Mussashi province (is now Ishida, Hino city, Tokyo).
He was born in Ishida village, Tama district, Musashi province (is now Ishida, Hino city, Tokyo).

sen.j: (6人兄弟の末っ子とされてきたが、近年になって発見された資料により、実は10人兄弟の末っ子であったことが判明した。)
sen.e: (He has been said to be the youngest among 6 brothers and sisters, but materials discovered in recent years revealed that he was actually the youngest among 10 brothers and sisters.)
(He has been said to be the youngest among 6 brothers and sisters, but materials discovered in recent years revealed that he was actually the youngest among 10 brothers and sisters.)
(He has been said to be the youngest among 6 brothers and sisters, but materials discovered in recent years revealed that he was actually the youngest among 10 brothers and sisters.)

sen.j: 土方家は、多摩地方に広がる豪農の家系で「お大尽」とよばれる大百姓であった。
sen.e: The HIJIKATA family were major farmers who come from a family line of rich farmers living widely in Tama region, that are called "Odaijin".
The HIJIKATA family was a wealthy farmer called "Odaijin" who had farmed on large stretches of land in the Tama region for generations.
The HIJIKATA family was a wealthy farmer called "Odaijin" who had farmed on large stretches of land in the Tama region for generations.

sen.j: 出生前に父を失っており、6歳の時に母も失い次兄の喜六夫妻に育てられる。
sen.e: He lost his father before birth and also lost his mother at the age of 6, and was brought up by his second oldest brother, Kiroku and Kiroku's wife.
He lost his father before he was born and his mother at the age of 6, and he was brought up by his second oldest brother, Kiroku and Kiroku's wife.
He lost his father before he was born and his mother at the age of 6, and he was brought up by his second oldest brother, Kiroku and Kiroku's wife.

sen.j: これまで11歳の時に江戸上野の「松坂屋いとう呉服店」（現在の松坂屋上野店）へ奉公に出、すぐに番頭と喧嘩をし、日野に戻ってきてしまった、と伝えられていたが、先ごろ発表された石田村の人別帳控により、数えの11歳時は石田村に在住しており、奉公には出ていないことが判明。
sen.e: Up to now, it has been said that he went to work at "Matsuzakaya Ito Gofuku store" (is now Matsuzakaya Ueno store) in Ueno, Edo at the age of 11, and soon quaralled with the head clerk and returned to Hino, but according to a copy of Ninbetsu-cho of Ishida village which has been made public recently, it has become clear that he has been living in Ishida village when he was 11 years old, and has not gone to work in the store.

Until now, it has been said that he went to work at "Matsuzakaya Ito Gofuku store" (present-day Matsuzakaya Ueno store) in Ueno, Edo at the age of 11, but soon quaralled with the head clerk and returned to Hino; according to a newly published copy of Ninbetsu-cho of Ishida village it became clear that he was living in Ishida village when he was 11 years old, and therefore had not yet gone to work at the store.
sen.cmt: 部分的に書き直し； 店名表記、確認できず
sen.e: Until now, it has been said that he went to work at "Matsuzakaya Ito Gofuku store" (present-day Matsuzakaya Ueno store) in Ueno, Edo at the age of 11, but soon quarreled with the head clerk and returned to Hino; according to a newly published copy of Ninbetsu-cho of Ishida village it became clear that he was living in Ishida village when he was 11 years old, and therefore had not yet gone to work at the store.

sen.j: 欠損もあるが、この人別帳から、歳三が奉公に出ていたのは数えで14歳～24歳の10年間と考えられるようになった。
sen.e: Although some parts are missing from this Ninbetsu-cho, it has come to be assumed that Toshizo went to work for a period of 10 years from the age of 14 to 24 (counted in the old Japanese way).
Although there are some missing parts based on this Ninbetsu-cho it is assumed that Toshizo went to work for a period of 10 years from the age of 14 to 24 (counted in the old Japanese way).
Although there are some missing parts based on this Ninbetsu-cho it is assumed that Toshizo went to work for a period of 10 years from the age of 14 to 24 (counted in the old Japanese way).

sen.j: 17歳の時には松坂屋上野店の支店である江戸伝馬町の木綿問屋（上野店の鶴店に対し、亀店（かめだな）と称された）に奉公に出され、そこで女性問題を起こして（番頭に衆道関係を迫られたとも言われている）日野に戻った、という伝説もあるが、前述の人別帳の存在から、現在ではその信憑性が疑問視されている。
sen.e: There is a legend that he was sent to work in a cotton wholesale store (was called Kamedana, in comparison with Ueno store which was called Tsurudana) in Edo Tenma-cho, a branch of Matsuzakaya Ueno store, but had problems with a woman there (there is also a rumour that he was forced sexual relationship by the head clerk) and returned to Hino, but due to the existence of the Ninbetsu-cho described above, reliability of such such stories are now doubted.

There is a legend that he was sent to work at a cotton wholesale store (called Kamedana, in comparison with the Ueno store which was called Tsurudana) in Edo Tenma-cho, a branch of Matsuzakaya Ueno store, but because he had problems with a woman there (there is also a rumour that he was forced into a sexual relationship by the head clerk) he returned to Hino; however, due to the existence of the Ninbetsu-cho described above, the reliability of such such stories are now in doubt.
sen.cmt: 部分的に書き直し； 鶴店、確認とれず
sen.e: There is a legend that he was sent to work at a cotton wholesale store (called Kamedana, in comparison with the Ueno store which was called Tsurudana) in Edo Tenma-cho, a branch of Matsuzakaya Ueno store, but because he had problems with a woman there (there is also a rumor that he was forced into a sexual relationship by the head clerk) he returned to Hino; however, due to the existence of the Ninbetsu-cho described above, the reliability of such stories are now in doubt.

sen.j: その後は実家秘伝の「石田散薬」を行商しつつ各地の道場で他流試合を重ね修業を積んだと言われる。
sen.e: Subsequently, it is said that he travelled and sold "Ishida Sanyaku medicine", for which the secrets in processing of the medicine has been passed on in his family, and at the same time trained himself by fighting many kenjutsu matches with other schools in Dojo's located in various areas.

Subsequently, it is said that he travelled and sold "Ishida Sanyaku medicine" whose secret recipe has been passed on in his family; at the same time he also trained himself by fighting in many swordsmanship matches with other schools in dojos located around the country.
sen.cmt: 石田散薬、裏づけとれず
sen.e: Subsequently, it is said that he traveled and sold "Ishida Sanyaku medicine" whose secret recipe has been passed on in his family; at the same time he also trained himself by fighting in many swordsmanship matches with other schools in dojos located around the country.

sen.j: 日野の佐藤道場に出稽古に来ていた天然理心流4代目の近藤勇（後の新選組局長）とはこの頃出会ったと推測され、安政6年（1859）3月29日、天然理心流に正式入門した。
sen.e: It is assumed that he met around that time Isami KONDO(who later became commander of Shinsen-gumi), the 4th Head of Tennen Rishin-ryu, who was visiting Sato Dojo in Hino for training, and on March 29 1859, Toshizo formally became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu.

It is around this time that he is assumed to have met Isami KONDO (who later became the commander of Shinsen-gumi), the 4th Head of Tennen Rishin-ryu, who was on a training trip to Sato Dojo in Hino; on March 29 1859, Toshizo formally became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu.

It is around this time that he is assumed to have met Isami KONDO (who later became the commander of Shinsen-gumi), the 4th Head of Tennen Rishin-ryu, who was on a training trip to Sato Dojo in Hino; on March 29 1859, Toshizo formally became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu.

sen.j: 歳三の姉佐藤のぶは姉弟の従兄弟でもある日野市日野宿名主の佐藤彦五郎に嫁いでおり、歳三も彦五郎宅にはよく出入りしていたと言われている。
sen.e: Toshizo's older sister, Nobu SATO, was married to Hikogoro SATO, who was also their cousin and Nanushi of Hino-jyuku, Hino city, and it is said that Toshizo often visited the residence of Hikogoro.

Toshizo's older sister, Nobu SATO, was married to Hikogoro SATO, who was also their cousin and Nanushi (an officer) of Hino-jyuku, Hino city; it is said that Toshizo often visited the residence of Hikogoro.

Toshizo's older sister, Nobu SATO, was married to Hikogoro SATO, who was also their cousin and Nanushi (headman of the city) of Hino-jyuku, Hino city; it is said that Toshizo often visited the residence of Hikogoro.
sen.cmt: 名主の説明を修正。派遣される官吏ではなく村の代表のこと。

sen.j: 彦五郎は大火に乗じて命を狙われたことがあり、それを契機に井上源三郎の兄、井上松五郎の勧めで天然理心流に入門、自宅の一角に道場を開いていた。
sen.e: Hikogoro had once been nearly killed during a major fire, and after such incident, he became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu, following the advice of Matsugoro INOUE, an older brother of Genzaburo INOUE, and Hikogoro started a Dojo in a corner of his house.

Hikogoro once was nearly killed during a major fire; after this incident, and on the advice of Matsugoro INOUE, an older brother of Genzaburo INOUE, Hikogoro became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu and started a Dojo in a corner of his house.

Hikogoro once was nearly killed during a major fire; after this incident, and on the advice of Matsugoro INOUE, an older brother of Genzaburo INOUE, Hikogoro became a disciple of Tennen Rishin-ryu and started a Dojo in a corner of his house.

sen.j: そんな縁から彦五郎は近藤と義兄弟の契りを結んでおり、天然理心流を支援した人でもある。
sen.e: Due to such background, Hikogoro took a pledge of brotherhood with KONDO, and supported Tennen Rishin-ryu.
Because of this background Hikogoro took a pledge of brotherhood with KONDO and supported Tennen Rishin-ryu.
Because of this background Hikogoro took a pledge of brotherhood with KONDO and supported Tennen Rishin-ryu.

sen.j: 歳三もこの道場で腕を磨いたと伝えられている。
sen.e: It is said that Toshizo also trained himself in kenjutsu at this Dojo.
It is said that Toshizo also trained himself in swordsmanship at this Dojo.
It is said that Toshizo also trained himself in swordsmanship at this Dojo.

sen.j: 近藤道場（試衛館）の仲間とともに、歳三は文久3年2月、幕府の征夷大将軍徳川家茂警護のための浪士組に応募して京都へ出立した。
sen.e: In 3rd Year of Bunkyu, February, Toshizo, together with his friends of Kondo Dojo (Shiei-kan), applied for the Roshigumi to guard Iemochi TOKUGAWA, Seii Taishogun of the Shogunate, and departed for Kyoto.

In February of the 3rd year of Bunkyu, Toshizo, together with his comrades of Kondo Dojo (Shiei-kan), applied for the Roshigumi to guard Iemochi TOKUGAWA, Seii Taishogun of the Shogunate, and departed for Kyoto.
sen.cmt: friends を comrades に変更
sen.e: In February of the 3rd year of Bunkyu, Toshizo, together with his comrades of Kondo Dojo (Shiei-kan), applied for the Roshigumi to guard Iemochi TOKUGAWA, Seii Taishogun of the Shogunate, and departed for Kyoto.

sen.j: 文久3年(1863)8月18日の八月十八日の政変後、壬生浪士組の活躍が認められ新選組が発足。
sen.e: After the political change on August 18 1863, the active role of Miburoshi-gumi was acknowledged, and Shinsen-gumi was set up.
After the political change on August 18 1863, the active role of Miburoshi-gumi was acknowledged, and Shinsen-gumi was set up.
After the political change on August 18 1863, the active role of Miburoshi-gumi was acknowledged, and Shinsen-gumi was set up.

sen.j: その後新見錦切腹、芹沢鴨などを自らの手で暗殺。
sen.e: Subsequently, Nishiki NIMI committed hara-kiri, and Toshizo directly assassinated Kamo SERIZAWA and some others.
Subsequently, Nishiki NIMI committed hara-kiri, and Toshizo directly assassinated Kamo SERIZAWA and some others.
Subsequently, Nishiki NIMI committed hara-kiri, and Toshizo directly assassinated Kamo SERIZAWA and some others.

sen.j: 権力をにぎった近藤勇が局長となった。
sen.e: Isami KONDO, who acquired power, became the commander.
Isami KONDO, who acquired power, became the commander.
Isami KONDO, who acquired power, became the commander.

sen.j: 歳三は副長の地位に就き、局長近藤勇の右腕として京都治安警護維持にあたった。
sen.e: Toshizo assumed the position as vice commander, and was engaged in maintaining peace and order in Kyoto, as Isami KONDO's right hand.
Toshizo assumed the position as vice commander, and as Isami KONDO's right hand man he engaged himself in maintaining peace and order in Kyoto.
Toshizo assumed the position as vice commander, and as Isami KONDO's right hand man he engaged himself in maintaining peace and order in Kyoto.

sen.j: 新選組は助勤、監察など職務ごとに系統的な組織作りがなされ、頂点は局長であるが、実際の指揮命令は副長の歳三から発せられるようになっていた。
sen.e: Systematic structure by each duty, such as Jyokin, Kansatsu, etc., of Shinsen-gumi was formed, and while the Head of the organization is the commander, actual directing orders were given by Toshizo, the vice commander.

Systematic structure by each duty such as Jyokin, Kansatsu, etc., of Shinsen-gumi was formed, and while the Head of the organization was the commander, the actual directing orders were given by Toshizo, the vice commander.
sen.cmt: 現在形から過去形に変更
sen.e: Systematic structure by each duty such as Jyokin, Kansatsu, etc., of Shinsen-gumi was formed, and while the Head of the organization was the commander, the actual directing orders were given by Toshizo, the vice commander.

sen.j: 元治元年（1864）6月5日池田屋事件の際は、半隊を率いて長州藩土佐藩藩士が頻繁に出入りしていた丹虎（四国屋）方面を探索して廻ったが、こちらは誰もいなかった。
sen.e: Upon Ikedaya Incident on June 5 1864, Toshizo lead half of the troop to search around Tantora (Shikokuya), visited frequently by members of the Choshyu clan and the Tosa clan, but nobody was there.
Upon Ikedaya Incident on June 5 1864, Toshizo lead half of the troop to search around Tantora (Shikokuya), visited frequently by members of the Choshyu clan and the Tosa clan, but nobody was there.
Upon Ikedaya Incident on June 5 1864, Toshizo lead half of the troop to search around Tantora (Shikokuya), visited frequently by members of the Choshyu clan and the Tosa clan, but nobody was there.

sen.j: すぐさま池田屋の応援に駆けつけたが、直ちに抜刀し踏み込まずに池田屋の周りを固め、後から駆けつけた会津藩、桑名藩の兵を池田屋に入らせず、新選組ただ一隊の手柄を守った。
sen.e: He promptly rushed to Ikedaya to assist and immediately had his men draw their swords from the sheath, but instead of entering the building they guarded the area around Ikedaya, so as not to allow soldiers from the Aizu clan and the Kuwana clan who arrived later, to enter Ikedaya, and thereby protected Shinsen-gumi's achievement as the only troop that handled the incident.

He promptly rushed to Ikedaya to assist and immediately had his men draw their swords from the sheaths, but instead of entering the building they guarded the area around Ikedaya in order to prevent the soldiers of the Aizu and the Kuwana clans (who would arrive later) from entering Ikedaya, thereby ensuring that only Shinsen-gumi would receive full credit for the achievement.

He promptly rushed to Ikedaya to assist and immediately had his men draw their swords from the sheaths, but instead of entering the building they guarded the area around Ikedaya in order to prevent the soldiers of the Aizu and the Kuwana clans (who would arrive later) from entering Ikedaya, thereby ensuring that only Shinsen-gumi would receive full credit for the achievement.

sen.j: まだ立場の弱い新選組の事を考えての行動だった。
sen.e: Such action were taken in consideration of the fact that Shinsen-gumi's position was still weak.
Such actions were taken with Shinsen-gumi's position, still weak at the time, in consideration.
Such actions were taken with Shinsen-gumi's position, still weak at the time, in consideration.

sen.j: 歳三らしい冷静な機転である。
sen.e: A tactful and calm action typical of Toshizo.
This was a tactful and calculating wit typical of Toshizo.
This was a tactful and calculating wit typical of Toshizo.

sen.j: そのため池田屋事件の恩賞は破格のものであり、勇名も一気に天下に轟いた。
sen.e: Consequently, rewards received for Ikedaya Incident were unprecedented, and their name became widely known throughout the country.
Consequently, rewards received for Ikedaya Incident were unprecedented, and their names became widely known throughout the country.
sen.cmt: name を names に変更
sen.e: Consequently, rewards received for Ikedaya Incident were unprecedented, and their names became widely known throughout the country.

sen.j: さらに幕府から、近藤を与力上席、隊士を与力とする内示まであったが、歳三は近藤を諌め与力よりも狙いは大名と、次の機会を待つよう進言し、近藤もこれを聞き入れた。
sen.e: The Shogunate unofficially notified to assign KONDO as Yoriki Joseki and Shinsen-gumi members as Yoriki, but Toshizo persuaded and adviced KONDO, that he should try to become a Daimyo rather than a Yoriki, and to wait for the next opportunity, and KONDO followed such advice.

The Shogunate unofficially notified to assign KONDO as Yoriki Joseki (Head of Additional Soldiers) and Shinsen-gumi members as Yoriki (Additional Soldiers), but Toshizo persuaded KONDO not to settle for a Yoriki, aim for a Daimyo instead and wait for the next opportunity; KONDO heeded his advice.
sen.cmt: 後半書き換え；上席の読み方確認できず
sen.e: The Shogunate unofficially notified to assign KONDO as Yoriki Joseki (Head of Additional Soldiers) and Shinsen-gumi members as Yoriki (Additional Soldiers), but Toshizo persuaded KONDO not to settle for a Yoriki, aim for a Daimyo instead and wait for the next opportunity; KONDO heeded his advice.

sen.j: 新選組内部では、常に新選組の規律を隊士らに遵守させ、規律を破った隊士に対しては切腹を命じており、隊士から恐れられていたとされる。
sen.e: Within Shinsen-gumi, he always made members follow the rules of Shinsen-gumi, and ordered a member who broke the rules to conduct hara-kiri, so it is said that the members feared him.
Within Shinsen-gumi, he always made members follow the rules of Shinsen-gumi and ordered a hara-kiri to the members who broke the rules; it is said that the members feared him.
Within Shinsen-gumi, he always made members follow the rules of Shinsen-gumi and ordered a hara-kiri to the members who broke the rules; it is said that the members feared him.

sen.j: そのため、新選組隊士の死亡原因第1位は切腹であったと言われている。
sen.e: Therefore, it is said that the top reason for death of a Shinsen-gumi was due to hara-kiri.
Therefore, it is said that the top reason for death of a Shinsen-gumi was due to hara-kiri.
Therefore, it is said that the top reason for death of a Shinsen-gumi was due to hara-kiri.

sen.j: また脱走者は切腹または斬殺後見せしめにすることもあった。
sen.e: Also, members who escaped from Shinsen-gumi were made to conduct hara-kiri, or were killed with a sword and exhibited as warning to others.
Also, members who escaped from Shinsen-gumi were made to conduct hara-kiri or were killed with a sword and [their bodies] exhibited as warning to others.
Also, members who escaped from Shinsen-gumi were made to conduct hara-kiri or were killed with a sword and [their bodies] exhibited as warning to others.

sen.j: その後、副長の山南敬助を総長に据え、副長は土方1人となる。
sen.e: Subsequently, the other vice commander, Keisuke YAMANAMI assumed the position of Soucho, and HIJIKATA became the only vice commander.
sen.cmt: 山南はさんなんという読み方も。
sen.e: Subsequently, the other vice commander, Keisuke YAMANAMI assumed the position of Soucho, and HIJIKATA became the only vice commander.
Subsequently, the other vice commander, Keisuke YAMANAMI assumed the position of Soucho, and HIJIKATA became the only vice commander.

sen.j: 隊の居場所がなくなり山南が脱走して切腹となった事件では、山南と土方との対立があったとされるが、実際は仲が良かったらしい。
sen.e: Regarding the incident where YAMANAMI lost his position within Shinsen-gumi and escaped, and was ordered to conduct hara-kiri, it is said that there was a dispute between YAMANAMI and HIJIKATA, but actually they seemed to have been good friends.

Regarding the incident where YAMANAMI was ordered to conduct a hara-kiri after he lost his position within Shinsen-gumi and escaped [and captured], it is said that there was a dispute between YAMANAMI and HIJIKATA, but actually they seemed to have been good friends.

Regarding the incident where YAMANAMI was ordered to conduct a hara-kiri after he lost his position within Shinsen-gumi and escaped [and captured], it is said that there was a dispute between YAMANAMI and HIJIKATA, but actually they seemed to have been good friends.

sen.j: その後も隊の規律を守るために河合耆三郎、谷三十郎、武田観柳斎らを切腹あるいは斬殺させた。
sen.e: After that, he also had Kisaburo KAWAI, Sanjyuro TANI, Kanryusai TAKEDA and some others conduct hara-kiri, or killed them by a sword, in order to maintain the order of Shinsen-gumi.
After that, he also had Kisaburo KAWAI, Sanjyuro TANI, Kanryusai TAKEDA and others conduct hara-kiri, or had them killed by a sword so as to maintain the order within Shinsen-gumi.
After that, he also had Kisaburo KAWAI, Sanjyuro TANI, Kanryusai TAKEDA and others conduct hara-kiri, or had them killed by a sword so as to maintain the order within Shinsen-gumi.

sen.j: 伊東甲子太郎の御陵衛士にスパイの斎藤一を送るなどして伊東の近藤暗殺計画を未然に防ぎ、伊東、藤堂平助を暗殺し御陵衛士達を壊滅させた（油小路事件）（御陵衛士、及び伊東に関しては異説有り）。
sen.e: He sent Hajime SAITO to Goryoeji formed by Kashitaro ITO, and took some other measures to successfully prevent ITO's plan to assassinate KONDO, and assassinated ITO and Heisuke TODO and completely destroyed Goryoeji (there are different stories regarding Goryoeji and ITO).

He sent Hajime SAITO to Goryoeji formed by Kashitaro ITO and took measures to successfully prevent ITO's plan to assassinate KONDO; he assassinated ITO and Heisuke TODO and completely destroyed Goryoeji (however, there are different stories regarding Goryoeji and ITO).

He sent Hajime SAITO to Goryoeji formed by Kashitaro ITO and took measures to successfully prevent ITO's plan to assassinate KONDO; he assassinated ITO and Heisuke TODO and completely destroyed Goryoeji (however, there are different stories regarding Goryoeji and ITO).

sen.j: 慶応3年（1867）6月に幕臣に取り立てられる。
sen.e: He was promoted to a vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate in June, 1867.
He was promoted to a vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate in June, 1867.
He was promoted to a vassal of the Tokugawa Shogunate in June, 1867.

sen.j: しかし同年10月14日に徳川慶喜が征夷大将軍を辞し大政奉還、12月9日に王政復古 (日本)の大号令が発せられるに至り、幕府は事実上崩壊。
sen.e: However, on October 14th of the same year, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA resigned from the position of Seii Taishogun, and upon Restoration of the Imperial Rule (Japan) on December 9th, the Shogunate essentially collapsed.

However, on October 14th of the same year, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA resigned from the position of Seii Taishogun, and upon Restoration of the Imperial Rule (Japan) on December 9th, the Shogunate essentially collapsed.

However, on October 14th of the same year, Yoshinobu TOKUGAWA resigned from the position of Seii Taishogun, and upon Restoration of the Imperial Rule (Japan) on December 9th, the Shogunate essentially collapsed.

sen.j: 慶応4年1月3日鳥羽・伏見の戦いに始まる戊辰戦争が勃発し、歳三は墨染事件で負傷した局長近藤勇の代わりに新選組を率いて戦うが、新政府軍の銃撃戦の前に敗北する。
sen.e: On 4th Year of Keio January 13th, Boshin War started with the Battle of Toba Fushimi, and Toshizo lead Shinsen-gumi and fought as a deputy of commander, Isami KONDO, who was wounded in Sumizome Incident, but was defeated against the army of the new government in gun fighting.

On January, 13th, 4th year of Keio, Boshin War started with the Battle of Toba Fushimi; in place of Isami KONDO, who was wounded in Sumizome Incident, Toshizo lead Shinsen-gumi and fought as a deputy of commander but was defeated against the army of the new government in gun fighting.
sen.cmt: 原文に近いように in place of 追加；墨染の読み方不明。
sen.e: On January, 13th, 4th year of Keio, Boshin War started with the Battle of Toba Fushimi; in place of Isami KONDO, who was wounded in Sumizome Incident, Toshizo lead Shinsen-gumi and fought as a deputy of commander but was defeated against the army of the new government in gun fighting.

sen.j: 歳三は鳥羽・伏見の戦いで敗北する以前の慶応元年頃から、これからは刀で戦ができない時代であると悟り、洋式の軍備を進め始める。
sen.e: From around the 1st Year of Keio, prior to being defeated in Battle of Toba Fushimi, Toshizo realized that from now on war cannot be fought with swords, and started to prepare westernized armaments.

From around the 1st year of Keio, prior to being defeated in Battle of Toba Fushimi, Toshizo realized that from now on war could not be fought with swords and he started to prepare western-style armaments.
sen.cmt: cannnot から could not に変更
sen.e: From around the 1st year of Keio, prior to being defeated in Battle of Toba Fushimi, Toshizo realized that from now on war could not be fought with swords and he started to prepare western-style armaments.

sen.j: 鳥羽・伏見の戦いで敗れた幕府軍が大阪から江戸へ撤退した後、近藤は大久保大和、歳三は内藤隼人と一時名乗って甲斐国に向かう。
sen.e: After the Shogunate army, who lost Battle of Toba Fushimi, retreated from Osaka to Edo, KONDO temporarily named himself Yamato OKUBO and Toshizo named himself Hayato NAITO, and they set off to Kai province.

After the Shogunate army lost Battle of Toba Fushimi and retreated from Osaka to Edo, KONDO temporarily named himself Yamato OKUBO and Toshizo named himself Hayato NAITO, and they set off to Kai province.

After the Shogunate army lost Battle of Toba Fushimi and retreated from Osaka to Edo, KONDO temporarily named himself Yamato OKUBO and Toshizo named himself Hayato NAITO, and they set off to Kai province.

sen.j: しかし3月6日甲州勝沼の戦いに敗退。
sen.e: However, on March 6th they were defeated in Battle of Kosyu Katsunuma.
sen.cmt: 甲州勝沼の戦いの表記、裏づけとれず
sen.e: However, on March 6th they were defeated in Battle of Kosyu Katsunuma.
However, on March 6th they were defeated in Battle of Kosyu Katsunuma.

sen.j: 歳三は急ぎ援軍要請に向かったが、成功しなかった。
sen.e: Toshizo rushed to request for reinforcements, but was not successful.
Toshizo rushed to request for reinforcements but was not successful.
Toshizo rushed to request for reinforcements but was not successful.

sen.j: その後、流山で再起を謀っていたが、4月3日不意の新政府軍包囲により局長近藤勇が新政府軍へ出頭。
sen.e: Subsequently, they were trying to recover power in Nagareyama, but on April 3rd, was suddenly surrounded by the army of the new government, and commander, KONDO, presented himself to the army of the new government.

Subsequently, they were trying to recover power in Nagareyama but on April 3rd, they were suddenly surrounded by the army of the new government; the commander, KONDO, surrendered himself to the army of the new government.

Subsequently, they were trying to recover power in Nagareyama but on April 3rd, they were suddenly surrounded by the army of the new government; the commander, KONDO, surrendered himself to the army of the new government.

sen.j: この時歳三が近藤の切腹を止めて出頭を勧めたと言われる。
sen.e: On this occasion, it is said that Toshizo stopped KONDO from committing hara-kiri, and persuaded KONDO to present himself to the army of the new government.
On this occasion, it is said that Toshizo stopped KONDO from committing hara-kiri, and persuaded KONDO to present himself to the army of the new government.
On this occasion, it is said that Toshizo stopped KONDO from committing hara-kiri, and persuaded KONDO to present himself to the army of the new government.

sen.j: 歳三は江戸へ向かい勝海舟らに直談判し近藤の助命を嘆願したが実現せず、慶応4年（1868）4月25日、近藤は板橋近辺（現JR板橋駅前に墓所有り）にて処刑（斬首）される。
sen.e: Toshizo went to Edo, and directly negotiated with Kaishu KATSU and others and pleaded to be spared KONDO's life, but was not successful, and KONDO was executed (beheaded) on April 25 1868, at a place close to Itabashi (currently, his tomb is located in front of JR Itabashi Station).

Toshizo went to Edo and directly negotiated with Kaishu KATSU and others and pleaded them to spare KONDO's life, but he was not successful; KONDO was executed (beheaded) on April 25 1868, at a place close to Itabashi (currently, his tomb is located in front of JR Itabashi Station).

Toshizo went to Edo and directly negotiated with Kaishu KATSU and others and pleaded them to spare KONDO's life, but he was not successful; KONDO was executed (beheaded) on April 25 1868, at a place close to Itabashi (currently, his tomb is located in front of JR Itabashi Station).

sen.j: 近藤出頭後、助命嘆願のかたわら新選組を斎藤一（山口二郎）に託して会津へ向かわせ、島田魁ら数名の隊士のみを連れて大鳥圭介らが率いる旧幕府脱走軍と合流。
sen.e: After KONDO presented himself to the army of the new government, Toshizo, besides pleading for KONDO's life, entrusted Shinsen-gumi in the care of Hajime SAITO (Jiro YAMAGUCHI) and made them go to Aizu, and Toshizo himself only took a few members including Kai SHIMADA and joined the army led by Keisuke OTORI and others, which was formed by men who escaped from the army of the former Shogunate.

After KONDO surrendered himself to the army of the new government, Toshizo, besides pleading for KONDO's life, entrusted Shinsen-gumi in the care of Hajime SAITO (Jiro YAMAGUCHI) and made them go to Aizu; Toshizo took only a few members including Kai SHIMADA and joined the army led by Keisuke OTORI and others, which was formed by men who escaped from the army of the former Shogunate.

After KONDO surrendered himself to the army of the new government, Toshizo, besides pleading for KONDO's life, entrusted Shinsen-gumi in the care of Hajime SAITO (Jiro YAMAGUCHI) and made them go to Aizu; Toshizo took only a few members including Kai SHIMADA and joined the army led by Keisuke OTORI and others, which was formed by men who escaped from the army of the former Shogunate.

sen.j: 4月11日に江戸城無血開城が成立すると江戸を脱走し、歳三は秋月登之助率いる先鋒軍の参謀を勤めた。
sen.e: On April 11th, when evacuation of Edo Castle without bloodshed succeded, Toshizo escaped from edo, and acted as a staff officer of the vanguard army lead by Noborinosuke AKIZUKI.
On April 11th, when evacuation of Edo Castle without bloodshed succeded, Toshizo escaped from Edo and acted as a staff officer of the vanguard army led by Noborinosuke AKIZUKI.
sen.cmt: lead を led に変更
sen.e: On April 11th, when evacuation of Edo Castle without bloodshed succeded, Toshizo escaped from Edo and acted as a staff officer of the vanguard army led by Noborinosuke AKIZUKI.

sen.j: 下館藩・下妻藩を経て宇都宮城の戦いに勝利、宇都宮城を陥落させる。
sen.e: They passed through the Shibodate clan, the Shimotsuma clan, and won Battle of Utsunomiya Castle, and conquered Utsunomiya Castle.
They passed through the Shimodate clan and the Shimotsuma clan, and won the Battle of Utsunomiya Castle and conquered Utsunomiya Castle.
They passed through the Shimodate clan and the Shimotsuma clan, and won the Battle of Utsunomiya Castle and conquered Utsunomiya Castle.

sen.j: しかし壬生の戦いに敗走、新政府軍と再度宇都宮で戦った際に足を負傷し、本軍に先立って会津へ護送されることとなった。
sen.e: However, they lost Battle of Mibu and fled, and fought again with the army of the new government in Utsunomiya, when Toshizo injured his leg, and he was escorted to Aizu before the main army went to Aizu.

However, they lost Battle of Mibu and fled; they fought again with the army of the new government in Utsunomiya during which Toshizo injured his leg; he was escorted to Aizu before the main army arrived in Aizu.

However, they lost Battle of Mibu and fled; they fought again with the army of the new government in Utsunomiya during which Toshizo injured his leg; he was escorted to Aizu before the main army arrived in Aizu.

sen.j: 会津では約3ヶ月間の療養生活を送り、この間に近藤勇の墓を天寧寺に建てたと言われる。
sen.e: In Aizu, he spent 3 months in recuperation, and it is said that during this time he built Isami KONDO's tomb in Tennei-ji Temple.
In Aizu, he spent 3 months in recuperation, and it is said that during this time he built Isami KONDO's tomb in Tennei-ji Temple.
In Aizu, he spent 3 months in recuperation, and it is said that during this time he built Isami KONDO's tomb in Tennei-ji Temple.

sen.j: 全快して戦線に復帰した後は会津の防戦に尽力するが、8月母成峠の戦いの敗戦に伴い会津戦争が激化。
sen.e: After he fully recovered and returned to the battle line, he endeavored to protect Aizu, but Battle of Aizu intensified as the result of losing Battle of Bonari-toge.
After he fully recovered and returned to the battle line he endeavored to protect Aizu, but Battle of Aizu intensified after they lost the Battle of Bonari-toge in August.
After he fully recovered and returned to the battle line he endeavored to protect Aizu, but Battle of Aizu intensified after they lost the Battle of Bonari-toge in August.

sen.j: 歳三は援軍を求めて庄内藩に向かうが、既に恭順体制の庄内においては入城さえ叶わなかった。
sen.e: Toshizo visited the Shonai clan to request for reinforcements, but Shonai, which was already allegiance to the new government, did not allow him to even enter the castle.
Toshizo visited the Shonai clan to request for reinforcements, but Shonai had already pledged allegiance to the new government and did not allow him to even enter the castle.
Toshizo visited the Shonai clan to request for reinforcements, but Shonai had already pledged allegiance to the new government and did not allow him to even enter the castle.

sen.j: 歳三は会津から仙台へ向かうことを決めた。
sen.e: Toshizo decided to depart for Sendai from Aizu.
Toshizo decided to depart for Sendai from Aizu.
Toshizo decided to depart for Sendai from Aizu.

sen.j: 同じように戦列を離れた大鳥圭介に対して山口二郎（斎藤一）らは会津藩に忠誠を尽くすべきだと訴えたというが、箱館で記録された後の古文書である。
sen.e: It is said that Jiro YAMAGUCHI (Hajime SAITO) and some others appealed to Keisuke OTORI who left the battle line in a way similar to Toshizo, that he should be loyal as possible to the Aizu clan, but this story is told by an old document which was recorded at a later date in Hakodate.

It is said that Jiro YAMAGUCHI (Hajime SAITO) and others appealed to Keisuke OTORI, who left the battle line in a way similar to Toshizo, that he should be as loyal as possible to the Aizu clan; however, this story comes from an old document which was recorded at a later date in Hakodate.
sen.cmt: as loyal as possible に変更
sen.e: It is said that Jiro YAMAGUCHI (Hajime SAITO) and others appealed to Keisuke OTORI, who left the battle line in a way similar to Toshizo, that he should be as loyal as possible to the Aizu clan; however, this story comes from an old document which was recorded at a later date in Hakodate.

sen.j: 土方は、会津藩領では新選組に復帰してはいなかった。
sen.e: HIJIKATA had not returned to Shinsen-gumi when they were in the domains of the Aizu clan.
HIJIKATA had not returned to Shinsen-gumi when they were in the domains of the Aizu clan.
HIJIKATA had not returned to Shinsen-gumi when they were in the domains of the Aizu clan.

sen.j: そして、城下に残る山口たちと仙台へ天寧寺から離脱した隊士たちと新選組は分裂する。
sen.e: Shinsen-gumi broke up into the group of YAMAGUCHI and others fho remained in the castle town, and the group of members who left at Tennei-ji temple
Shinsen-gumi broke up into the group of YAMAGUCHI and others who remained in the castle town and the group of members who left at Tennei-ji temple.
Shinsen-gumi broke up into the group of YAMAGUCHI and others who remained in the castle town and the group of members who left at Tennei-ji temple.

sen.j: 仙台に至り榎本武揚率いる旧幕府海軍と合流。
sen.e: Toshizo arrived in Sendai, and joined the navy of the former Shogunate, lead by Takeaki ENOMOTO.
Toshizo arrived in Sendai and joined the navy of the former Shogunate led by Takeaki ENOMOTO.
sen.cmt: lead から led に変更
sen.e: Toshizo arrived in Sendai and joined the navy of the former Shogunate led by Takeaki ENOMOTO.

sen.j: 榎本とともに奥羽越列藩同盟の軍議に参加し、同盟軍総督に推薦されたが、まもなく奥羽越列藩同盟が崩壊、同盟藩が次々と新政府軍に屈服した後は、戦う地がある限りどこまでも戦うことを決意。
sen.e: Together with ENOMOTO, Toshizo participated in military meetings of Ouetsu Reppan Domei (Northern Alliance), and was recommended to become General of Domei Army, but Ouetsu Reppan Domei soon collapsed, and after the clans which formed Domei Army surrended one after another to the army of the new government, Toshizo decided to fight wherever he can, so long as there is a place where he can fight.

Together with ENOMOTO Toshizo participated in military meetings of Ouetsu Reppan Domei (Northern Alliance) and was recommended to become General of Domei Army; however, Ouetsu Reppan Domei soon collapsed, and after the clans forming the Domei Army surrended one after another to the army of the new government, Toshizo decided to fight until the end, so long as there is a place where he can fight.
sen.cmt: 同盟軍総督の裏づけとれず；「どこまでも戦う」は「最後まで戦う」という意味だと思うので until the end にしました。
sen.e: Together with ENOMOTO Toshizo participated in military meetings of Ouetsu Reppan Domei (Northern Alliance) and was recommended to become General of Domei Army; however, Ouetsu Reppan Domei soon collapsed, and after the clans forming the Domei Army surrended one after another to the army of the new government, Toshizo decided to fight until the end, so long as there is a place where he can fight.

sen.j: 新選組生き残り隊士に桑名藩士らを加えて大江丸に乗船し、榎本武揚らとともに10月12日仙台折浜（現宮城県石巻市折浜）を出航、蝦夷に渡った。
sen.e: Shinsen-gumi members who remained alive, together with men from the Kuwana clan, boarded Oemaru, and with Takeaki ENOMOTO and others left Orinohama, Sendai (currently, Orinohama, Ishinomaki city, Miyagi prefecture) on October 12th, and went to Ezo.

The Shinsen-gumi members who remained alive boarded Oemaru along with the men from the Kuwana clan, and they left Orinohama, Sendai (currently, Orinohama, Ishinomaki city, Miyagi prefecture) with Takeaki ENOMOTO and others on October 12th and went to Ezo.
sen.cmt: 大江丸の読み方、裏づけとれず
sen.e: The Shinsen-gumi members who remained alive boarded Oemaru along with the men from the Kuwana clan, and they left Orinohama, Sendai (currently, Orinohama, Ishinomaki city, Miyagi prefecture) with Takeaki ENOMOTO and others on October 12th and went to Ezo.

sen.j: 土方歳三像
sen.e: The image of Toshizo HIJIKATA
The image of Toshizo HIJIKATA
The image of Toshizo HIJIKATA

sen.j: 10月20日、蝦夷地鷲の木に上陸後、歳三は間道軍総督となり五稜郭へ向かった。
sen.e: After landing on Washinoki of Ezo on October 20th, Toshizo became General of Kando Army and headed for Goryokaku.
sen.cmt: 間道軍総督の裏づけとれず。間道はわきみちのこと
sen.e: After landing on Washinoki of Ezo on October 20th, Toshizo became General of Kando Army and headed for Goryokaku.
After landing on Washinoki of Ezo on October 20th, Toshizo became General of Kando Army and headed for Goryokaku.

sen.j: 新選組は大鳥圭介総督の下本道を進んだが、歳三には島田魁ら数名の新選組隊士が常に従っていたと言う。
sen.e: Shinsen-gumi travelled by the main road under the leadership of General Keisuke OTORI, but a few members of Shinsen-gumi including Kai SHIMADA, are said to have followed Toshizo.
Shinsen-gumi travelled by the main road under the leadership of General Keisuke OTORI, but a few members of Shinsen-gumi including Kai SHIMADA, are said to have followed Toshizo.
Shinsen-gumi traveled by the main road under the leadership of General Keisuke OTORI, but a few members of Shinsen-gumi including Kai SHIMADA, are said to have followed Toshizo.

sen.j: 箱館・五稜郭を占領後、歳三は額兵隊などを率いて松前へ進軍し松前城（福山城）を陥落させ、残兵を江差まで追撃した。
sen.e: After occupying Goryokaku, Toshizo advanced his army, leading Gakuheitai army, etc., and conquered Matsumae Castle (Fukuyama Castle), and chased the retreating army of the enemy to Esashi.

After occupying Goryokaku in Hakodate Toshizo advanced his army including Gakuheitai army and others.; he conquered Matsumae Castle (Fukuyama Castle) and chased the retreating army of the enemy to Esashi.
sen.cmt: 函館が抜けてたので追加
sen.e: After occupying Goryokaku in Hakodate Toshizo advanced his army including Gakuheitai army and others.; he conquered Matsumae Castle (Fukuyama Castle) and chased the retreating army of the enemy to Esashi.

sen.j: この時、榎本武揚は土方軍を海から援護するため、開陽丸で江差沖へ向かったが、暴風雨に遭い座礁。
sen.e: On this occasion, Takeaki ENOMOTO went to the offing of Esashi in order to support HIJIKATA's family from the sea, but his ship was stranded because of a storm.
On this occasion, Takeaki ENOMOTO went to the offing of Esashi in order to support HIJIKATA's family from the sea, but his ship was stranded because of a storm.
On this occasion, Takeaki ENOMOTO went to the offing of Esashi in order to support HIJIKATA's family from the sea, but his ship was stranded because of a storm.

sen.j: 江差に上陸して開陽丸の沈没していく姿を見守っていた榎本と歳三は、そばにあった松を叩いて嘆き合ったと言われ、今でもその「嘆きの松」が残っている。
sen.e: ENOMOTO, who landed in Esashi to watch Kaiyomaru sink, and Toshizo are said to have punched a pine tree which stood nearby and lamented together, and the "Nageki no Matsu" (pine tree of lament) remains today.

ENOMOTO, who landed in Esashi, and Toshizo watched Kaiyomaru sink, and they are said to have punched a pine tree which stood nearby and lamented together; the "Nageki no Matsu" (pine tree of lament) still remains today.
sen.cmt: 榎本と歳三の両人が開陽丸の沈没をみていたと原文から読めるのでそのように変更；嘆きの松、表記確認できず
sen.e: ENOMOTO, who landed in Esashi, and Toshizo watched Kaiyomaru sink, and they are said to have punched a pine tree which stood nearby and lamented together; the "Nageki no Matsu" (pine tree of lament) still remains today.

sen.j: 江差を無事占領した歳三は、一度松前城へ戻り、12月15日榎本が各国領事を招待して催した蝦夷地平定祝賀会に合わせて五稜郭へ凱旋した。
sen.e: Toshizo, who managed to occupy Esashi, temporarily returned to Matsumae Castle, and returned to Goryokaku on December 15th, for the Celebration of Conquest of Ezo held by ENOMOTO, to which ENOMOTO invited the consuls of various countries.

Toshizo, who managed to occupy Esashi, temporarily returned to Matsumae Castle; he returned to Goryokaku on December 15th for the Celebration of Conquest of Ezo held by ENOMOTO, to which ENOMOTO invited the consuls of various countries.
sen.cmt: 松前城の後にセミコロン使用
sen.e: Toshizo, who managed to occupy Esashi, temporarily returned to Matsumae Castle; he returned to Goryokaku on December 15th for the Celebration of Conquest of Ezo held by ENOMOTO, to which ENOMOTO invited the consuls of various countries.

sen.j: その後、幹部を決定する選挙が行われ、榎本を総裁とする蝦夷共和国（五稜郭が本陣）が成立、歳三は幹部として陸軍奉行並となり、箱館市中取締や陸海軍裁判局頭取も兼ねた。
sen.e: Subsequently, an election to determine leaders was held, and Ezo Republic (headquarters in Goryokaku) was established, and Toshizo, as one of the leaders, became vice-minister of the Army, and concurrently served as Torishimari of Hakodate city, and chief of the Court of the Army and the Navy.

Subsequently, an election to determine leaders was held, and Ezo Republic (headquarters in Goryokaku) was established; Toshizo, as one of the leaders, became vice-minister of the Army and concurrently served as Torishimari of Hakodate city and chief of the Court of the Army and the Navy.
sen.cmt: 歳三の前にセミコロン使用
sen.e: Subsequently, an election to determine leaders was held, and Ezo Republic (headquarters in Goryokaku) was established; Toshizo, as one of the leaders, became vice-minister of the Army and concurrently served as Torishimari of Hakodate city and chief of the Court of the Army and the Navy.

sen.j: 箱館の地でも歳三は冷静だったと言う。
sen.e: It is said that Toshizo remained calm in Hakodate.
It is said that Toshizo remained calm in Hakodate.
It is said that Toshizo remained calm in Hakodate.

sen.j: 箱館政府が樹立され、榎本らが祝杯を交わしているときも歳三は一人沈黙を保ち、「今は騒ぎ浮かれる時ではない」と言っていたと伝わる。
sen.e: There is a story that, when Hakodate government was established, and ENOMOTO and others were drinking in celebration, Toshizo alone remained silent, and said that "this is not the time for jubilation".
When ENOMOTO and others were drinking to celebrate the establishment of the Hakodate government Toshizo alone remained silent and said "this is not the time for jubilation".
When ENOMOTO and others were drinking to celebrate the establishment of the Hakodate government Toshizo alone remained silent and said "this is not the time for jubilation."

sen.j: 1月から2月にかけては箱館・五稜郭の整備にあたり、3月には新政府軍襲来の情報が入ったため、歳三は新政府軍の東艦奪取を目的とした宮古湾海戦に参加、作戦は失敗し多数の死傷者が出るも、歳三は生還する。
sen.e: He was engaged in consolidating Hakodate/Goryokaku from January to February, and when the news of an attack by the army of the new government reached his ears in March, Toshizo participated in Naval Battle of Miyakowan which targeted to seize Azuma-kan of the army of the new government, but this operation failed, and many were wounded or died, but Toshizo managed to safely return.

He was engaged in consolidating Hakodate/Goryokaku from January to February, and when the news of an attack by the army of the new government reached his ears in March Toshizo participated in Naval Battle of Miyakowan which targeted to seize Azuma-kan of the army of the new government; however, this operation failed, and many died or were wounded, but Toshizo managed to return safely.
sen.cmt: 最後の部分でセミコロン使用
sen.e: He was engaged in consolidating Hakodate/Goryokaku from January to February, and when the news of an attack by the army of the new government reached his ears in March Toshizo participated in Naval Battle of Miyakowan which targeted to seize Azuma-kan of the army of the new government; however, this operation failed, and many died or were wounded, but Toshizo managed to return safely.

sen.j: 明治2年（1869）4月9日、新政府軍が蝦夷地乙部に上陸を開始。
sen.e: On April 9 1869, the army of the new government started to land in Otobe, Ezo.
On April 9, 1869, the army of the new government started to land in Otobe, Ezo.
On April 9, 1869, the army of the new government started to land in Otobe, Ezo.

sen.j: 歳三は、二股口の戦いで新政府軍の進撃に対し徹底防戦する。
sen.e: Toshizo made every effort to defend against the attacks of the army of the new government in Battle of Futamataguchi.
Toshizo made every effort to defend against the attacks of the army of the new government in Battle of Futamataguchi.
Toshizo made every effort to defend against the attacks of the army of the new government in Battle of Futamataguchi.

sen.j: その戦闘中に新政府軍は鈴の音を鳴らし、包囲したと思わせる行動をとり、自軍が包囲されたと思った土方軍は動揺した。
sen.e: During the battle, the army of the new government used tactics where they rang bells, and misleaded the enemy in thinking that they were surrounded, and HIJIKATA army who thought that they were surrounded, was upset.
During the battle, the army of the new government rang bells to trick the enemy into thinking that they were surrounded; HIJIKATA's army thought that they were surrounded and was upset.
During the battle, the army of the new government rang bells to trick the enemy into thinking that they were surrounded; HIJIKATA's army thought that they were surrounded and was upset.

sen.j: これに対し歳三は「本当に包囲しようとするなら、音を隠し気づかれないようにする。」と冷静に状況を判断し、部下を落ち着かせた。
sen.e: Toshizo calmly judged the circumstances, and calmed his men down by telling them that "if our enemy really wished to surround us, they will hide all noise so that we will not notice them".
Toshizo calmly judged the circumstances and calmed his men down by telling them that "if our enemy really wished to surround us they would hide all noises so that we will not notice them".

sen.e: Toshizo calmly judged the circumstances and calmed his men down by telling them that "if our enemy really wished to surround us they would hide all noises so that we will not notice them."

sen.j: また、戦いの合間に歳三は部下達に自ら酒を振舞って廻った。
sen.e: Also, in between the fighting, Toshizo himself went around and offered his men a drink.
Also, in between the fighting, Toshizo himself went around and offered his men a drink of sake.
Also, in between the fighting, Toshizo himself went around and offered his men a drink of sake.

sen.j: そして「酔って軍律を乱してもらっては困るので皆一杯だけだ」と言ったので、部下は笑って了承したと言う。
sen.e: He told them that "only one drink for each of you, as I do not want you to get drunk and break the rules of the army"to which comment his men laughed and agreed.
He told them "only one drink for each of you, as I do not want you to get drunk and break the rules of the army"; his men laughed and agreed.
He told them "only one drink for each of you, as I do not want you to get drunk and break the rules of the army"; his men laughed and agreed.

sen.j: 土方軍が死守していた二股口は連戦連勝。
sen.e: Futamataguchi, which HIJIKATA army defended desparately, continued to win a series of battles.
Futamataguchi, which HIJIKATA army defended desparately, continued to win a series of battles.
Futamataguchi, which HIJIKATA army defended desparately, continued to win a series of battles.

sen.j: しかし、もう一方の松前口が破られて退路が絶たれる危険が起こったため、やむなく二股口を退却、五稜郭へ帰還した。
sen.e: However, the other entrance, Matsumaeguchi, fell under the attacks of the enemy, and as there was a risk that it will become impossible for them to retreat, they had no choice but to return to Goryokaku.
However, the other entrance at Matsumaeguchi fell under the attacks of the enemy, and as there was a risk of losing a route for a retreat they had no choice but to return to Goryokaku.
However, the other entrance at Matsumaeguchi fell under the attacks of the enemy, and as there was a risk of losing a route for a retreat they had no choice but to return to Goryokaku.

sen.j: 歳三の命によって台場方面に進軍していた大野率いる兵士らは一時勢力を盛り返していたが、突然乱れて大野の必死の指揮にも関わらず総崩れとなった。
sen.e: The soldiers lead by OHNO, who were advancing to the direction of Daiba under the order of Toshizo, were temporarily regaining their power, but were suddenly out of order, and despite OHNO's desperate instructions, suffered a total defeat.

The soldiers lead by OHNO, who were advancing in the direction of Daiba under the order of Toshizo, were temporarily regaining their power, but they suddenly lost control and suffered a total defeat despite OHNO's desperate instructions.

sen.j: 大野がやむを得ず引き返したところ、同じく陸軍奉行添役の安富才助から歳三の戦死を知らされたと言う。
sen.e: OHNO had no choice but to return, and he was informed by Saisuke YASUTOMI, who was also an Assistant General of the Army, that Toshizo had died in battle.
OHNO had no choice but to return, and he was informed by Saisuke YASUTOMI, who was also an Assistant General of the Army, that Toshizo had died in the battle.

sen.j: 歳三の遺体は小芝長之助らに引き取られて、他の戦死者と共に五稜郭に埋葬されたとも、別の場所に安置されていたとも言われる。
sen.e: Toshizo's body was claimed by Chonosuke KOSHIBA and others, and is said to have been buried in Goryokaku with the bodies of others who died in the war, or to have been laid at another place.

sen.e: Just before his death, Toshizo handed locks of his hair to be kept as a memonto and his photograph to Tetsunosuke ICHIMURA, who served him as Kosyo, and ordered Tetsunosuke to "deliver them to my family".

sen.j: 行商中に学んだ様々な流派のクセが取れなかったようだ。
sen.e: It seems that he could not get rid of the ways of various schools which he learnt while he was traveling as a peddler.

sen.j: しかし、実戦では滅法強かったと言われている（斬り合いの時、足下の砂を相手にぶつけてひるんだ隙に斬り伏せたり首を絞めて絞殺したりなど、縦横無尽に戦闘をしていたという）。
sen.e: Nevertheless, it is said that he was awfully strong in actual fighting (it is said that he actively fought, by such ways as throwing the sand on the ground at his opponent, and cutting the opponent down or strangling him, while the opponent flinched from Toshizo's attack).

Nevertheless, it is said that he was awfully strong in actual fighting (it is said that he fought with no restraints, for example, by throwing the sand on the ground at his opponent and slashing or strangling him while heflinched from Toshizo's initial attack).

sen.j: 後の洋装の写真などから、歳三は合理主義者で便利なものは便利と受け取る柔軟さをもっており、舶来の懐中時計なども持っていたという。
sen.e: As can be seen by his photo of a later year dressed in western clothing, it is said that Toshizo was a rationalist, and had the flexibility to accept useful things, and owned a western pocket watch, etc.

As can be seen from his photo of a later year dressed in western clothing, it is said that Toshizo was a rationalist and had the flexibility to accept useful things; for example, he owned a western pocket watch, etc.

sen.e: As can be seen from his photo of a later year dressed in western clothing, it is said that Toshizo was a rationalist and had the flexibility to accept useful things; for example, he owned a western pocket watch, etc.

sen.j: 隊内の気の置けない仲間には、「自分は、織田信長の生まれ変わりだろう。」と言ったことがある。
sen.e: He once said to colleagues of Shinsen-gumi who were close to him, "probably I am reborn from Nobunaga ODA".
He once said to colleagues of Shinsen-gumi who were close to him, "probably I am reborn from Nobunaga ODA".
He once said to colleagues of Shinsen-gumi who were close to him, "probably I am reborn from Nobunaga ODA".

sen.j: 陣中法度、局中法度などの厳しい隊規を考案したとされ、裏切り者やはみ出し者に容赦の無い刃を浴びせた歳三は、鬼の副長と呼ばれ普段は冷酷な人物とされる。
sen.e: It is said that he created strict rules for Shinsen-gumi, such as Jinchu Hatto and Kyokuchu Hatto, and mercilessly killed betrayers or those who did not follow the rules, and was referred to as the pitiless vice commander, and is said to have been generally a heartless person.

It is said that he created strict rules for Shinsen-gumi, such as Jinchu Hatto and Kyokuchu Hatto, and mercilessly killed betrayers or those who did not follow the rules; he was referred to as the pitiless vice commander, and in general, he was considered to be a heartless person.

sen.j: しかし、箱館戦争にまで従った新選組隊士中島登によれば、箱館戦争当時には「温和で、母のように慕われていた」という。
sen.e: However, according to Nobori NAKAJIMA who followed Toshizo up to Hakodate War, at the time of Hakodate War "he was mild and was loved by his men as if he was their mother".
However, according to Nobori NAKAJIMA who followed Toshizo up to Hakodate War, at the time of Hakodate War "he was mild and was admired by his men as if he was their mother".

sen.e: However, there is a view that this was not because he has become older, but because he almost sensed that he has found a place to die, and also because he tried to motivate his men, who may die fighting even on the following day.

sen.j: もともと色白で引き締まった顔立ちをしており（当時としては）長身であった為、京都にて新選組副長として活動していたときなどは、日野の仲間に向けて多数の女性からの恋文をまとめて送って自慢するほどであった。
sen.e: He was handsome with a fair complexion and firm features and was a tall man(at his time), so when he was acting as the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi in Kyoto, he sent a bundle of love letters he had received from many women, to his colleagues in Hino, to boast how popular he was.

Because he was a tall (for that time), handsome man with a fair complexion and firm features he was very popular among ladies; when he was acting as the vice commander of Shinsen-gumi in Kyoto he sent to his colleagues in Hino a bundle of love letters he had received from many women so as to boast his popularity.

sen.j: 宇都宮の戦いで足を負傷していた歳三は、慶応4年（1868）閏4月頃から7月頃（異説あり）まで、会津若松城下の宿で病床に伏していた。
sen.e: Toshizo, who has wounded his leg in Battle of Utsunomiya, was in sickbed at an inn in the castle town of Aizu Wakamatsu from around April to July of Year 1868 (there are different views regarding the period).

sen.e: One day, Mitsuzo MOCHIZUKI, who was a vassal of the Shogunate and a public servant, and stayed at the same inn as Toshizo, visited him, but Toshizo remained in his bed and said "fight with us".
